intro: Xylocarpus antila, commonly known as the Antillean mangrove, is a species of flowering plant in the family Malvaceae. It is characterized by its woody structure and ability to thrive in brackish water environments. The plant has thick, fibrous roots that help anchor it in coastal soils and filter out salt. Its flowers are small and clustered, producing a distinctive, fragrant scent. Xylocarpus antila plays an important ecological role in stabilizing shorelines and providing habitat for various marine and terrestrial species.
